qas.question: What does the W and Z boson exchange create?
What is the observable effect of W and Z boson exchange?

answers.text: beta decay (of neutrons in atomic nuclei)

qas.question: What is the effect of beta decay?
How many times less is the strenght of the weak field compared to the strong?
At what temperature do weak and electromagnetic forces appear the same?

plausible_answers.text: the heavy W and Z bosons

qas.question: The strong force is due to the exchange of what?
Alpha decay is the most familiar effect of what force?
What force is weaker than gravity over short distances?
What electroweak theory has not been developed?

context: The <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><a0_3><b6_0><b7_0>weak<b7_0/><b6_0/> force<a0_3/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> is due to the exchange of <b5_0>the heavy W and Z bosons<b5_0/>. Its most familiar effect is <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><a1_3>beta decay<a1_3/><a1_2/><a1_0/> (of neutrons in atomic nuclei)<a1_1/> and the associated <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><a2_3>radioactivity<a2_3/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>. The word "weak" derives from the fact that the field strength is some <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><a3_3>1013<a3_3/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> times less than that of the strong force. Still, it is stronger than gravity over short distances. A <b8_0>consistent<b8_0/> electroweak theory has also been developed, which shows that electromagnetic forces and the weak force are indistinguishable at a temperatures <a4_1><a4_3>in excess of <a4_0>approximately <a4_2>1015 kelvins<a4_3/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>. Such temperatures have been probed in modern particle accelerators and show the conditions of the universe in the early moments of the Big Bang.
